choices.text: Careful Aspiration for CSF to rule out Intrathecal Placement
﻿﻿Use of Test Dose with Lignocaine and Adrenaline
Incremental Injection of Local Anaesthetic in Small Doses
﻿All of the above

questions.text: Which of these steps will help in preventing Total Spinal Anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D. Each of steps can help in the prevention of Total Spinal Anesthesia by ensuring correct placement of the Epidural or Caudal Needle and by careful administration of the local Anesthetic.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aspirating for Cerebro-Spinal Fluid (CSF) is a crucial step to ensure that the needle or catheter is not in the intrathecal space, which would lead to a total spinal anesthesia if a large volume of local anesthetic were injected.

 

Option B. A test dose with lignocaine and adrenaline can help identify intravascular or intrathecal placement. Adrenaline causes a transient increase in heart rate and blood pressure if injected into a blood vessel, and lignocaine will cause a block if injected intrathecally.

 

Option C. Administering local anesthetic in small, incremental doses allows for the assessment of the anesthetic effect and can prevent the sudden onset of a Total Spinal Anesthesia by reducing the chance of a large volume entering the intrathecal space at once.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To prevent total spinal anesthesia during epidural or caudal anesthesia, it is essential to carefully aspirate for CSF to avoid intrathecal injection, use a test dose with lignocaine and adrenaline to detect incorrect needle placement, and incrementally inject local anesthetic in small doses.

 

Total Spinal Anesthesia:

 

  • Intracranial spread of local anesthetic is called as Total Spinal Anesthesia
  • Occurs following accidental intrathecal injection in Epidural/Caudal Anesthesia
  • Accompanied by Hypotension, Bradycardia, Apnoea, and loss of consciousness.

 

Prevention of Total Spinal Anesthesia:

 

  • Careful aspiration for CSF to rule out Intrathecal Placement.
  • ﻿﻿Use of test dose with Lignocaine and Adrenaline
  • Incremental Injection of Local Anaesthetic in Small Doses

 

Ref: Miller's Anesthesia 8th Edition • Page no: 1047, 1715

choices.text: General Anesthesia causes more Morbidity.
Spinal Anesthesia is easier to Administer in Older Males.
Spinal Anesthesia helps in keeping patient Awake and identifying Electrolyte Disturbances.
General Anesthesia can cause increased Absorption of Irrigating Fluid.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with hypertension, diabetes and benign prostatic hyperplasia of prostate is posted for transurethral resection of prostate (TURP). The Anesthesia of choice in this case is Spinal Anesthesia because:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spinal Anesthesia helps in keeping patient Awake and identifying Electrolyte Disturbances.

 

Option C: This is correct. Spinal anesthesia allows the patient to remain conscious, which can be crucial for the early identification of TURP syndrome—a potentially life-threatening complication characterized by acute hyponatremia due to the absorption of irrigation fluids.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While it's true that general anesthesia may have more associated morbidity compared to regional techniques in certain populations, this is not the specific reason spinal anaesthesia is preferred for TURP.

 

Option B. The choice of anesthesia is more often based on the benefits of the anesthesia type for the specific procedure rather than the ease of administration.

 

Option D. General anesthesia does not directly cause increased absorption of irrigating fluid; rather, it is the surgical procedure itself that poses this risk. However, under General Anesthesia, it might be harder to recognize the early symptoms of TURP syndrome as the patient is unconscious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spinal Anesthesia is preferred for Trans-Urethral Resection of the Prostate (TURP) because it allows the patient to remain conscious, aiding in the early detection of TURP syndrome by monitoring for signs of electrolyte disturbances, particularly hyponatremia.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition page 1300

choices.text: 4th Cranial Nerve
6th Cranial Nerve
7th Cranial Nerve
9th Cranial Nerve

questions.text: A 54-year-old female was posted for total knee replacement. She had Osteoarthritic changes in her spine and thus, the Anesthesiologist took 4 attempts at Spinal Anesthesia. Post-operatively, the patient complained of severe headache and was diagnosed with post-Dural Puncture Headache. What is the Cranial Nerve that could be Paralyzed in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6th Cranial Nerve

 

Option B: The Abducens Nerve, or Cranial Nerve VI, innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye. It is the most commonly affected cranial nerve in cases of increased intracranial pressure and can also be affected by the traction on intracranial structures due to CSF volume changes after a dural puncture, leading to diplopia when looking laterally.

 

6th cranial nerve is most commonly affected during spinal anesthesia.

 

Mechanism of Headache- Dural puncture causes excessive loss of CSF leading to reduction in CSF volume. This can cause downward pulling or stretching of the intracranial contents. Cranial nerves, vessels, dura and brain parenchyma may be injured by stretching leading to complications such as sixth nerve palsy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Trochlear Nerve, or Cranial Nerve IV, innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye, which is primarily involved in rotary movements. Palsy of this nerve typically results in diplopia (double vision) that is most noticeable when looking downwards. This nerve is not typically affected by changes in intracranial pressure that can occur with a post-dural puncture headache (PDPH).

 

Option C. The Facial Nerve, or Cranial Nerve VII, controls the muscles of facial expression, taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and some other functions. It is not typically associated with PDPH or changes in CSF pressure.

 

Option D. The Glosso-Pharyngeal Nerve, or Cranial Nerve IX, is involved in taste and other functions of the posterior third of the tongue and pharynx. It is not associated with the symptoms of PDPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sixth cranial nerve is the most commonly affected nerve in post-dural puncture headache (PDPH), likely due to the stretching of the nerve as a consequence of reduced intracranial CSF pressure. This can result in lateral rectus palsy and cause diplopia, which is a characteristic sign of sixth nerve palsy.

 

Ref: Millers textbook of Anesthesia, 9th edition page 1441.

questions.text: While performing subarachnoid block what is the level below which the spinal needle is inserted?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L2-L3

 

Explanation:

 

 

The spinal cord normally extends from the foramen magnum to the level of lower border of L1 in adults. So, in adults we can give spinal anesthesia below this level in L2/L3, L3/L4. In children, the spinal cord ends at L3 and moves up with age.

 

Therefore, performing a lumbar (subarachnoid) puncture below L1 in an adult (L3 in a child) usually avoids potential needle trauma to the spinal cord. Damage to the cauda equina is unlikely as these nerve roots float in the Dural sac below L1 and tend to be pushed away (rather than pierced) by an advancing needle.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1796

choices.text: Caudal Anesthesia
Epidural Anesthesia

questions.text: A 24-year-old young truck driver has developed a Fissure in Ano. What would be the Ideal Anesthesia for this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Saddle Anesthesia

 

Option C: Saddle block, a variant of spinal anesthesia, is administered while the patient is in a sitting position, and the patient remains sitting for several minutes afterward. This allows the anesthetic to affect primarily the lower lumbar and sacral nerves, which is sufficient for a fissure in ano surgery. It avoids extensive nerve blocking, which minimizes hemodynamic changes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Caudal anesthesia, is a type of regional anesthesia that is often used in pediatric patients for surgeries involving the lower body, such as hernia repair or circumcision. While it could theoretically be used in adults for anal fissure surgery, it is less commonly chosen due to the complexity and potential for complications in adults.

 

Option B. Epidural anesthesia involves the injection of anesthetic in the epidural space. It is typically used for procedures involving the lower limbs and abdomen. For a localized procedure such as surgery for a fissure in ano, epidural anesthesia may be more extensive than necessary.

 

Option D. Spinal anesthesia is a broader form of regional anesthesia that can affect a large segment of the body from the injection site downward. While it could be used for anal fissure surgery, the extent of nerve blocking is usually more than what is needed for such a localized procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Saddle anesthesia is ideal for surgeries in the perineal region, such as a fissure in ano, as it provides targeted anesthesia to the sacral nerves without extensive blockade of the thoracolumbar spinalnerves, thereby minimizing hemodynamic alterations.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1830

questions.text: A 3-month-old child is undergoing surgical repair of umbilical hernia under general anesthesia. Identify the procedure performed in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Caudal Anaesthesia

 

Option A: Caudal anesthesia is a common regional anesthetic technique used in children for surgeries below the umbilicus. The procedure involves inserting a needle through the sacral hiatus to access the epidural space at the caudal end of the spinal column. This matches the procedure depicted in the image, where the landmarks of the sacral cornua are used to guide needle insertion.

 

The above image shows a caudal block which is a type of central neuraxial block, most commonly used in pediatrics to provide analgesia for surgeries up to the umbilicus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Spinal anesthesia involves the injection of anesthetic into the subarachnoid space and is typically performed at higher levels of the spine, not at the sacral hiatus. Spinal anesthesia is not commonly used in infants due to the risks associated with administering a spinal block at such a young age.

 

Option C. Similar to caudal anesthesia, Epidural anesthesia technique involves the injection of anesthetic into the epidural space, but it is usually performed at higher vertebral levels. While the caudal block is a type of epidural anesthesia, the term "epidural anesthesia" alone usually refers to lumbar or thoracic epidural injections.

 

Option D. Saddle anesthesia is a specific type of spinal anesthesia that affects only the lower extremities and perineal area, resembling the area where a saddle would be. This type of block is not depicted in the image, as it would not be performed in the sacral area for an umbilical hernia repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caudal anesthesia is a form of regional anesthesia used primarily in the pediatric population for procedures below the umbilicus, utilizing the sacral hiatus as the entry point for the anesthetic. It is commonly used due to its safety and effectiveness for sub-umbilical surgical procedures in children.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1840

questions.text: After inserting a thoracic epidural catheter for an exploratory Laparotomy, the Anesthesiologist wants to check the placement of the catheter. Thus, a Test Dose is given through it. He takes 3ml of Lignocaine + Adrenaline mixture to be given. What is the Concentration of Adrenaline added to Lignocaine for test dose?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1:200000

 

Explanation:

 

Epidural test dose consists of 45 mg of lidocaine with 15 micrograms of epinephrine as the ideal epidural test dose. The aim of an epidural test dose is to avoid the consequences of injecting a critical amount of local anesthetic either intravascularly, subdurally, or intrathecally. An ideal test dose should allow the detection of all needles/catheters misplaced in one of these three locations, should never give false-positive response that would lead to unnecessary catheter repositioning or manipulation, and should never induce serious side effects.

 

The classic test dose combines Local Anesthetic and Adrenaline, 3 mL of 1.5% Lidocaine with 1: 200,000 Epinephrine. This Adrenaline, if injected Intravascularly would increase the Heart Rate by 20% with or without the rise in Blood Pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Millers Textbook of Anesthesia, 9th Edition Page 876

choices.text: Sphenopalatine Nerve Block

questions.text: Which of these should not be used for the treatment of Postdural Puncture Headache?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Standing Position.

 

Option A: Standing or sitting in an upright position is not recommended for the treatment of Post-Dural Puncture Headache (PDPH). This position may worsen the headache due to the effect of gravity, which can exacerbate the leakage of Cerebro-Spinal Fluid (CSF) through the puncture site, leading to further lowering of CSF pressure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Administration of Intravenous (IV) fluids is part of the conservative treatment for PDPH. It helps to maintain hydration and can support the production of CSF, potentially aiding in the resolution of the headache.

 

Option C. Sphenopalatine nerve block is an interventional treatment option for PDPH where a local anesthetic is applied to the sphenopalatine ganglion via the nasal mucosa. It can help relieve the headache by blocking the associated nerve pathway.

 

Option D. Stool softeners are recommended to avoid straining during bowel movements, which can increase intracranial pressure and potentially worsen a PDPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standing position should be avoided in the treatment of PDPH because it can exacerbate the leakage of CSF and worsen the headache. Conservative treatment typically includes recumbent positioning, analgesics, hydration, and caffeine. Additional interventions like sphenopalatine ganglion block or the use of stool softeners can also be beneficial.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1850

questions.text: Identify the last layer punctured to enter the Epidural Space?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ligamentum Flavum

 

Explanation:

 

Epidural space is a circular space surrounding the dural sac and all of its extensions. It is a potential space exists between the lining of the vertebral canal and the dural sac.

 

Contents- Areolar Tissue, Fat, Spinal Nerve Root with their Dural Sleeves, Spinal Arteries, Capillary Network which forms the venous plexus.

 

Structures which are penetrated to reach the Epidural Space- Skin and Subcutaneous Tissue, Supraspinous Ligament, Interspinous Ligament, Ligamentum Flavum.

 

Site of Action of Local Anesthetic Drug in Epidural Space:

  • On the Nerves as they traverse the Epidural Space
  • On the Nerves as they pass out through the Intervertebral Foramina
  • On the Nerves in the Subarachnoid Space-The local anesthetic agent reaches the epiduralspace by diffusion through the dura.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Structures Pierced in Lumbar Puncture

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1830-1834

questions.text: What is the Gold Standard for management of PDPH?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epidural Blood Patch

 

Option D. The Epidural Blood Patch is indeed the gold standard treatment for PDPH. It involves the injection of autologous blood into the epidural space to form a clot, which seals the dural puncture and stops CSF leakage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While rest is a part of the conservative management for postdural puncture headache (PDPH), it is not the gold standard treatment. Rest can help alleviate symptoms but does not address the underlying cause of the CSF leak.

 

Option B. Hydration is also a supportive measure to help with PDPH by potentially increasing CSF production, but it is not the definitive treatment for the condition.

 

Option C. Cerebral vasoconstriction – caffeine and NSAIDs. These medications can provide symptomatic relief for PDPH by causing cerebral vasoconstriction and reducing pain. However, they are not considered the gold standard treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epidural blood patch is the gold standard for the management of postdural puncture headache, as it directly addresses the cause of the headache by sealing the dural puncture site and stopping CSF leakage.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1850

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Identify the use of this Needle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epidural Anesthesia

 

Option B. The Tuohy Needle, characterized by its curved, blunt tip, is specifically designed to administer epidural anesthesia by threading a catheter through it into the epidural space without piercing the dura mater. The blunt, curved tip theoretically helps to push away the dura after passing through the ligamentum flavum instead of penetrating it.

 

This is Tuohy’s needle used for Epidural Anesthesia. Another classic identification feature of Tuohy needle is alternate light and dark markings on needle as shown in the image

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The design with a curved tip is not typical for spinal needles, which are usually smaller in gauge and have a sharper point.

 

Option C. While lumbar punctures do require a needle to access the subarachnoid space, the Tuohy needle is not typically used for this procedure because its design is meant to reduce the risk of dural puncture, which is necessary for obtaining cerebrospinal fluid during a lumbar puncture.

 

Option D. All of the above. Although needles are used in all the listed procedures, the Tuohy needle is specifically designed for epidural anesthesia and not typically used for spinal anesthesia or lumbar puncture.

 

Educational Objective:

The Tuohy needle, recognized for its curved,blunt tip, Alternate light and dark markings on needle, is primarily used for the administration of epidural anesthesia and is designed to minimize the risk of dural puncture.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1834

choices.text: Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity
Total Spinal Anesthesia
High Spinal Anesthesia

questions.text: A 25-year-old Primigravida is given 15 ml of 0.25% Heavy Bupivacaine for Lower Segment Caesarean Section (LSCS) in the Epidural Space. She developed Hypotension, Respiratory Arrest and became unconscious within 2minutes, what could be the cause for the same?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total Spinal Anesthesia

 

Option B: If Local Anesthetic is inadvertently injected into the Cerebrospinal Fluid during an attempt at Epidural Anesthesia, it can lead to a blockade of the entire Spinal Cord and Brainstem, resulting in Hypotension, Respiratory Arrest, and loss of Consciousness, as described in the scenario.

 

Intracranial Spread of Local Anesthetic is called as Total Spinal Anesthesia. It is characterized by symptoms like Slurred Speech, Sedation and loss of Consciousness. lt can occur following Epidural Anaesthesia/Analgesia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Local anesthetic systemic toxicity - This condition occurs when a high plasma level of local anesthetic affects the central nervous system and cardiovascular system, leading to symptoms such as seizures, cardiac arrhythmias, and even cardiac arrest. However, the rapid onset of unconsciousness and respiratory arrest described in the question is less typical for systemic toxicity, which usually presents with CNS excitation before depression.

 

Option C. High spinal anesthesia occurs when local anesthetic is injected into the subarachnoid space and affects a large portion of the spinal cord, potentially leading to extensive sympathetic blockade and paralysis of the chest and upper abdominal muscles. While it can cause severe Hypotension and Respiratory difficulty, the rapid progression to unconsciousness is more indicative of a total spinal.

 

Option D. An allergic reaction to drugs can cause symptoms such as rash, itching, swelling, and in severe cases, anaphylaxis. Respiratory arrest and unconsciousness are possible but would typically be accompanied by other signs of allergy, which are not described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total spinal anesthesia refers to the inadvertent spread of local anesthetic to the cranial subarachnoid space during epidural anesthesia, leading to severe hypotension, respiratory arrest, and loss of consciousness. Management includes airway support, oxygen, vasopressors, and intravenous fluids.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1848

choices.text: S1 Upper Border
S1 Lower Border
S2 Upper Border
S2 Lower Border

questions.text: The Dural Sac in Adults ends at:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) S2 Lower Border

 

Explanation:

 

Spinal cord in adults ends at lower border of L1

Spinal cord in children ends at upper border of L3

Dural sac in adults ends at lower border of S2

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dural sac in adults ends at lower border of S2

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 5th Edition Page 943,944

questions.text: While giving Spinal Anesthesia, the order of loss of Sensory Blockade is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Temperature — Pain — Touch — Pressure

 

Explanation:

 

The correct order of Sensory Loss under Spinal Anesthesia is:

 

Option A. Temperature — Pain — Touch — Pressure

 

This sequence occurs because different sensory fibers vary in their diameter, myelination, and conduction velocity, which influences their sensitivity to local anesthetics. The fibers that carry temperature and pain sensations are smaller and more sensitive, so they are blocked first, followed by fibers that carry touch, and finally, those that carry pressure sensations.

 

Pre-Ganglionic Sympathetic Fibers (B Fibers), which are involved in autonomic function, are the most sensitive to local anesthetic blockade. The larger A-alpha motor fibers are more resistant than any of the sensory fibers, which explains why motor blockade occurs after sensory blockade during spinal anesthesia.

 

Recovery from the block occurs in the reverse order of the loss, meaning pressure sensation returns first, followed by touch, pain, and temperature. This knowledge is crucial for clinicians to anticipate the patient's recovery process and manage postoperativecare effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Order of Blockade of Nerve Fibers: Autonomic > Sensory > Motor

 

Order of Sensory Blockade: Temperature (Cold)> Pain(pinprick)>Touch> proprioception

 

Pre-Ganglionic Sympathetic Fibers (B fibers) are most sensitive to Local Anesthetic Blockade.

 

The Larger A-Alpha Motor Fibers are more resistant than any of the Sensory Fibers.

 

Recovery from Block is in Reverse Order.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th Edition Page 1688

questions.text: What is the last layer to be punctured while performing spinal anesthesia/Lumbar Puncture?
questions.solution:
Ans C. Arachnoid Mater

 

Explanation:

 

Structures Pierced in Lumbar Puncture

 

Educational Objective:

 

The last layer to be punctured while performing spinal anesthesia or a lumbar puncture is the arachnoid mater, which is directly followed by the entry into the subarachnoid space containing the cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition page 1700

choices.text: Baricity of Drug
Height of Patient

questions.text: Which of these factors don’t affect the spread of local anesthetic drug in spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Height of Patient

 

Option D: Height of the patient is often considered to be a less significant factor in the spread of Local Anesthetic during Spinal Anesthesia. While it might seem that taller individuals would have a greater spread due to a longer spinal column, research and clinical experience suggest that height is not a reliable predictor of anesthetic spread, which is why it is often not considered a major factor in determining the dose or level of blockade.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Age can affect the spread of local anesthetic in spinal anesthesia. In older patients, the spinal column may have calcified ligaments and reduced intervertebral disc height, potentially affecting the spread of the anesthetic.

 

Option B. The baricity of the anesthetic solution relative to CSF determines how the drug will behave upon injection into the subarachnoid space. Hyperbaric solutions tend to sink, hypobaric solutions rise, and isobaric solutions remain where they are injected.

 

Option C. Pregnancy can affect the spread of spinal anesthesia due to physiological changes such as an increase in intra-abdominal pressure and a potential decrease in the volume of the spinal canal, leading to a higher spread of the local anesthetic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The height of the patient does not significantly affect the spread of local anesthetic in spinal anesthesia compared to factors such as the baricity of the drug, patient age, and physiological changes during pregnancy.

 

FACTORS AFFECTING SPREAD OF SPINAL ANESTHESIA:

 

Characteristics of the Local Anesthetic Solution

  • Baricity
  • Local anesthetic dose
  • Local anesthetic concentration
  • Volume injected

 

Patient Characteristics

  • Age
  • Weight
  • Gender
  • Pregnancy
  • Patient position

 

Technique

  • Site of injection
  • Speed of injection
  • Barbotage
  • Direction of needle bevel
  • Addition of vasoconstrictors

 

Diffusion

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition pg 1694-1695

choices.text: None of the above

questions.text: During a Spinal Block, an Anesthesiologist notes that the patient has a well-defined band of anesthesia at certain nerve roots, while the nerve roots above and below are unblocked. This clinical finding is referred to as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Differential Block

 

Explanation:

 

The phenomenon described is a differential block, which occurs due to the varying sensitivity of nerve fibers to local anesthetics. The clinical manifestations of a differential block are as follows:

 

  • Sympathetic Block: This occurs at the highest level because the pre-ganglionic sympathetic fibers (B fibers) are the smallest and most myelinated, making them the most sensitive to local anesthetic agents. The sympathetic block is often judged by a loss of temperature sensitivity since sympathetic nerves regulate blood flow and temperature sensation.
  • Anesthesia to Cold Sensation: Corresponding with the sympathetic block, the patient loses sensation to cold due to the blockade of the same fibers that carry temperature sensation.
  • Anesthesia to Pinprick Sensation: Occurs approximately two dermatomes lower than the sympathetic block. The fibers that transmit pain and temperature (A-delta and C fibers) are more resistant to local anesthetics than the sympathetic fibers.
  • Anesthesia to Touch Sensation: Occurs approximately one to two dermatomes lower than the block to pinprick sensation. The fibers that transmit touch (A-beta fibers) are larger and even more resistant to local anesthetics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A differential block in spinal anesthesia is characterized by the blockade of sympathetic fibers at the highest level, followed by sensory fibers responsible for cold sensation, then pinprick, and finally, touch sensation, reflecting the varying sensitivities of different nerve fibers to local anesthetics.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 2059

choices.text: Incidence is reduced by Cutting Spinal Needles as compared to Pencil Point Needles
Epidural Blood Patch is the Gold Standard Treatment.
Headache is relieved by Caffeine.
It is seen more in Younger Patients rather than Older Patients.

questions.text: Which is of the following is not true regarding post dural puncture headache?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Incidence is reduced by Cutting Spinal Needles as compared to Pencil Point Needles.

 

Option A: This statement is not true. Pencil point needles, such as the Whitacre or Sprotte, are designed to part the fibers of the dura mater rather than cut them, which leads to a lower incidence of PDPH compared to cutting needles like the Quincke.

 

  • Incidence of PDPH is more in younger age group, females, pregnant, obese, increased number of attempts at spinal/epidural anesthesia.
  • Needle size: pencil point needles with smaller gauge have lesser incidence of PDPH.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. This is true. An epidural blood patch is considered the gold standard treatment for Post-Dural Puncture Headache (PDPH). It involves injecting autologous blood into the epidural space to form a clot that seals the dural puncture.

 

Option C. This is true. Caffeine is a central nervous system stimulant that causes cerebral vasoconstriction. It can provide temporary relief from the headache associated with PDPH by increasing cerebrospinal fluid production and reducing cerebral blood flow.

 

Option D. This is true. PDPH is more commonly seen in younger patients. The elasticity of the dura is thought to be greater in younger patients, making it less likely to close back up after being punctured, leading to CSF leakage and PDPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incidence of Post-Dural Puncture Headache (PDPH) is actually reduced by using pencil point spinal needles instead of cutting needles, as they are less likely to cause a dural tear that can result in CSF leakage.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1850

choices.text: Combined Spinal Epidural Set.

questions.text: Identify the equipment given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Combined Spinal Epidural Set.

 

Explanation:

 

The contents of a Combined Spinal-Epidural (CSE) set typically include the following items:

 

  1. Epidural Needle: This is usually a Tuohy needle that is used to access the epidural space.
  2. Spinal Needle: A thinner needle that can pass through the epidural needle to access the subarachnoid space.
  3. Epidural Catheter: This is threaded through the epidural needle into the epidural space for continuous administration of medication.
  4. Introducer Needle: This may be included to facilitate the insertion of the spinal needle.
  5. Syringes: Used for administering local anesthetic and for aspiration to confirm correct placement in the epidural space.
  6. LOR (Loss of Resistance) Syringe or Device: This is used to detect the loss of resistance that indicates entry into the epidural space.
  7. Sterile Drapes, Gloves, and Cleaning Solution: For maintaining a sterile field during the procedure.
  8. Adhesive Tape or Dressing: To secure the catheter in place.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Combined Spinal-Epidural (CSE) Anesthesia set typically contains the following contents:

 

  1. Epidural needle (usually a Tuohy needle)
  2. Spinal needle (often a smaller gauge needle, which may be a Whitacre or Sprotte to minimize the risk of post-dural puncture headache)
  3. Epidural catheter for continuous administration of medication
  4. Syringes for injecting local anesthetics and other medications
  5. Introducer needle for the epidural catheter
  6. Loss of resistance syringe or device to identify the epidural space
  7. Sterile drapes and skin cleansing solution
  8. Local anesthetic agents for both spinal and epidural anesthesia
  9. Adhesive dressings to secure the catheter in place
  10. Optional: epidural filter

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 9th Edition Page 1428

choices.text: 1- No motor block
﻿3- Complete block of motor limb
﻿﻿﻿2- Inability to raise extended leg and move knee; able to move feet.
﻿﻿﻿All of the above are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of these is not a correct Grade of Modified Bromage scale?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1- No motor block

 

Explanation:

 

Modified BromageScale – used to test the adequacy of motor blockade after spinal/epidural anesthesia.

 

0- No motor block

1- ﻿Inability to raise extended leg; Able to move knees and feet.

2- ﻿﻿﻿Inability to raise extended leg and move knee; Able to move feet.

3- ﻿﻿﻿Complete block of motor limb

 

Other techniques to check for adequacy of motor blockade – electromyography, spirometry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Modified Bromage Scale is a clinical tool used to assess the degree of motor block in patients who have received spinal or epidural anesthesia. It ranges from 0 (no motor block) to 3 (complete motor block). Option A is incorrect because a score of 1 on the scale represents some motor block, not no motor block.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 9th Edition Page 1432

questions.text: Which of these is a relative contraindication to Neuraxial/Regional Anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sepsis  

 

Option C: Sepsis is a relative contraindication for neuraxial or regional anesthesia due to the risk of introducing infection into the central nervous system or exacerbating an existing systemicinfection. Bacteremia poses a risk for developing meningitis or an epidural abscess if the infection is spread via the needle or catheter.

 

Contraindications to Central Neuraxial Blockade

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Controlled hypertension is not a relative contraindication to neuraxial or regional anesthesia. In fact, regional anesthesia can be beneficial in hypertensive patients by providing stable hemodynamicsduring surgery. However, severe uncontrolled hypertension may increase the risk of bleeding complications and needs careful consideration.

 

Option B. Patients with chronic renal disease are not absolutely contraindicated for neuraxial or regional anesthesia, but caution is advised due to potential alterations in drug metabolism and elimination, as well as an increased risk of bleeding due to uremic platelet dysfunction.

 

Option D. Diabetes is not a relative contraindication to neuraxial or regional anesthesia. However, diabetic patients might have associated complications such as neuropathy or a higher risk of infection that should be considered when planning anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sepsis is a relative contraindication to neuraxial or regional anesthesia due to the risk of central nervous system infection. Each patient's individual risks and benefits must be evaluated when considering regional anesthesia, especially in the presence of systemic infections.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1806

choices.text: Bezold – Jarisch Reflex
Block of Cardio- Accelerator Fibers of Synthetic Origin
Reverse Bainbridge Reflex

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient was given Subarachnoid Block with Bupivacaine (Heavy) by the Anesthetist. After 10 minutes he was found to have a BP of 70/44 mm Hg and Heart Rate of 49/min. On checking the level of block, it was found to be T5. What is the likely explanation for Bradycardia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bezold – Jarisch Reflex

 

Option A: Bezold-JarischReflex is a complex cardiovascular reflex that can cause bradycardia, hypotension, and coronary artery vasodilation. It is triggered by the activation of mechanoreceptors in a poorly filled ventricle, which can occur following vasodilation from spinal anesthesia, leading to decreased venous return and cardiac output. This is the likely cause of the bradycardia in the patient.

 

The Bezold–Jarisch reflex has been suggested as a possible cause of profound bradycardia and circulatory collapse after spinal anesthesia and interscalene brachial plexus block.

 

The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is a cardioinhibitory reflex defined as bradycardia, vasodilation, and hypotension resulting from stimulation of cardiac receptors. It originates from inhibitory mechanoreceptors in the left ventricle (particularly the inferoposterior wall). Stimulation of these inhibitory cardiac receptors by stretch (poorly filled ventricle after vasodilation due to spinal anesthesia), chemical substances or drugs increases parasympathetic activity and inhibits sympathetic activity. These effects promote reflex bradycardia, vasodilation and hypotension.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Bainbridge reflex involves an increase in heart rate due to an increase in venous return and atrial pressure. It is the opposite of what is described in the scenario, where there is a decrease in blood pressure and heart rate.

 

Option C. While the block of cardio-accelerator fibers can cause bradycardia, the level of block (T5) is too low to affect these fibers, which typically exit the spinal cord at levels T1 to T4.

 

Option D. There is no widely recognized physiological reflex known as the "Reverse Bainbridge reflex." The Bainbridge reflex refers to the increase in heart rate that occurs with increased venous return.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is likely responsible for bradycardia and hypotension following spinal anesthesia with a high level of block, as it leads to an underfilled ventricle and subsequent reflex bradycardia and vasodilation.

 

Ref: https://litfl.com/bezold-jarisch-reflex

choices.text: Use of Opioids as Additives
High Spinal Anesthesia

questions.text: Which of these is the major contributory factor to peri- operative nausea and vomiting in cases done under central neuraxial blockade?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypotension

 

Explanation:

 

Factors associated with Peri-Operative Nausea or Vomiting after Neuraxial Blockade:

 

Major factor – Hypotension

 

Other factors:

 

  1. ﻿﻿Gastrointestinal Hyperperistalsis because of Unopposed Parasympathetic Activity
  2. ﻿﻿Opioids
  3. ﻿﻿High Spinal Anesthesia, above T5
  4. ﻿﻿Addition of Phenylephrine or Epinephrine to the Local Anesthetic
  5. ﻿﻿History of Motion Sickness

 

Rx – IV Fluids, Atropine

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypotension is the primary cause of peri-operative nausea and vomiting during neuraxial blockade due to sympathetic nerve blockade leading to vasodilation and decreased blood pressure.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th Edition Page 1691

questions.text: A 20-year-old primigravida, full term gestation was given labor analgesia 10 ml of bupivacaine 0.125% as bolus dose through epidural catheter. In which of these situations is labour epidural analgesia not recommended?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

 

Contraindications to Neuraxial Block (Spinal & Epidural)

 

  • Absolute: Infection at the Site of Injection, patient Refusal, coagulopathy or other bleeding disorder, severe hypovolemia, increased intracranial pressure, severe aortic or mitral stenosis.
  • Relative: Sepsis, uncooperative patient, pre-existing neurological deficit, demyelinating lesions, severe spinal deformity, stenotic valvular heart disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The contraindications to labor epidural analgesia include patient refusal, hypovolemia, and uncorrected coagulopathy, to ensure patient safety and avoid complications associated with neuraxial blocks.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1806

choices.text: Requirement of Local Anesthetic Drug is Increased.
There is an Increase in Cardiac Output.
There is a Decrease in Venous Return.
Hypotension is uncommon.

questions.text: Which of these statements about Epidural Anesthesia in Pregnancy is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) There is a Decrease in Venous Return.

 

Option C: Correct. In pregnant patients, the enlarging uterus can compress the inferior vena cava when the patient is in the supine position, leading to decreased venous return. This effect can be exacerbated by the vasodilation caused by epidural anesthesia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. During pregnancy, particularly in the context of epidural anesthesia, there is actually a decreased requirement for local anesthetic drugs due to physiological changes, such as increased sensitivity to local anesthetics and the distension of the epidural venous plexus.

 

Option B. Incorrect. Cardiac output may decrease during epidural anesthesia in pregnancy due to a reduction in venous return, especially if hypotension occurs as a side effect.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Hypotension is actually a common side effect of epidural anesthesia, particularly in pregnant patients due to the combined effects of the anesthesia and the physiological changes of pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant patients receiving epidural anesthesia, there is typically a decreased requirement for local anesthetic drugs and a common occurrence of hypotension, often due to a decrease in venous return from the compression of the inferior vena cava by the enlarging uterus.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1570

choices.text: Posterior Superior Iliac Spine

questions.text: A 1 year old male is posted for umbilical hernia repair under general anesthesia with caudal analgesia. The child was positioned in left lateral position and the area was painted and draped. The anesthesiologist used a 22G needle to enter the caudal canal through sacral hiatus. Which structure must be pierced to enter the caudal epidural space?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sacrococcygeal Membrane

 

Option B: Correct. The Sacrococcygeal Membrane is an extension of the ligamentum flavum and overlies the sacral hiatus between the two sacral cornua. During caudal epidural anesthesia, when the needle is advanced through the sacrococcygeal membrane into the caudal epidural space, a loss of resistance is felt.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. The posterior superior iliac spine is a bony landmark on the iliac crest of the pelvis. It is not directly involved in the administration of caudal epidural anesthesia and does not offer the resistance felt when a needle penetrates the sacrococcygeal membrane.

 

Option C. Incorrect. The dura mater is the outermost layer of the meninges surrounding the brain and spinal cord. While it is indeed punctured during midline epidural anesthesia, the sacrococcygeal membrane is the structure encountered during caudal epidural anesthesia.

 

Option D. Incorrect. While sacral ligaments are involved in the stability of the sacral region, they are not the specific site where the loss of resistance is felt during the administration of caudal epidural anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During caudal epidural anesthesia, the needle penetrates the sacrococcygeal membrane, and a loss of resistance is felt as it enters the caudal epidural space. This membrane is an extension of the ligamentum flavum covering the sacral hiatus.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th edition page 1840

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida with term pregnancy is posted for emergency LSCS due to fetal distress leading to fetal bradycardia. What is the type of anesthesia preferred in this emergency situation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) General Anesthesia

 

Option A: Correct. In an emergency situation such as fetal distress leading to fetal bradycardia, there is often not enough time to prepare and perform regional anesthesia. General anesthesia is preferred for its rapid onset, which is crucial in emergencies, and because it allows for airway control and better hemodynamic management.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Incorrect. While epidural anesthesia is commonly used in planned cesarean sections due to its benefits for both mother and child, it requires time for placement and onset of action, which may not be suitable in an emergency situation.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Spinal anesthesia is another form of regional anesthesia that could be used for cesarean sections but, like epidural anesthesia, it is not preferred in emergency situations due to the time it takes to become effective.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Local anesthesia is not adequate for a cesarean section, as it does not provide sufficient analgesia for such an invasive procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In emergency obstetric situations requiring immediate surgical intervention, such as fetal distress with fetal bradycardia, general anesthesia is often the preferred choice due to its rapid onset and the ability to manage the patient's airway and hemodynamics effectively.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th Edition Pg 2345

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Which of these is useful for prevention/ treatment of post-neuraxial shivering?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D: Correct. All the listed options are useful in the prevention and treatment of post-neuraxial shivering. They act through various mechanisms to reduce shivering and provide comfort to the patient undergoing neuraxial blocks.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Correct. IV Meperidine is an opioid analgesic that has been shown to be effective in reducing post-neuraxial shivering. Its mechanism may be related to its kappa-opioid receptor agonist effects and its action on the thermoregulatory centers.

 

Option B. Correct. Epidural fentanyl can also be used to treat post-neuraxial shivering. It provides analgesia and can reduce shivering without significantly affecting the core body temperature.

 

Option C. Correct. IV Pethidine, which is another name for meperidine, is effective in the treatment of post-neuraxial shivering. Its effects are similar to meperidine due to its action on opioid receptors and its effect on thermoregulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prevention and treatment of post-neuraxial shivering can be effectively managed with various pharmacological agents, including IV meperidine (or IV pethidine, as they are the same drug), and epidural fentanyl. These agents act through different mechanisms to reduce shivering associated with neuraxial anesthesia.

 

Ref: Miller's Anesthesia 8th edition • Page no: 1715

questions.text: Which is the most commonly used vasopressor to counter hypotension due to autonomic blockade in neuraxial anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ephedrine

 

Option A: Correct. Ephedrine is a sympathomimetic amine commonly used to counter hypotension due to autonomic blockade in neuraxial anesthesia. It works by indirectly stimulating adrenergic receptor systems and increasing the activity of norepinephrine at the postsynaptic α and β receptors, leading to increased blood pressure and cardiac output.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Incorrect. While epinephrine is a potent vasopressor, it is not the most commonly used drug to counteract hypotension in neuraxial anesthesia due to its potent β-adrenergic effects, which can lead to tachycardia and other cardiac effects.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Noradrenaline (norepinephrine) is a powerful vasopressor that primarily acts on α-adrenergic receptors leading to vasoconstriction. It is used in severe hypotension but is not the first choice for hypotension due to neuraxial anesthesia.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Adrenaline is another potent vasopressor with both α and β-adrenergic effects. It is typically used in life-threatening situations such as anaphylaxis or cardiac arrest, rather than routine management of hypotension from neuraxial blockade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of hypotension due to neuraxial anesthesia commonly involves the use of IV fluids and directly acting vasopressors like ephedrine, which increases systolic and diastolic blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output through indirect stimulation of adrenergic receptors. Ephedrine is the preferred vasopressor because it provides a balanced increase in both heart rate and blood pressure, which is beneficial in the setting of neuraxial anesthesia-induced hypotension.

 

Ref: Miller's Anesthesia 8th Edition • Page no: 2334

questions.text: A 55-year-old female is posted for right total hip replacement. After giving spinal anesthesia, patient starts complaining of nausea, vomiting and BP falls to 80/40 mm hg. Which of these would not be a part of the treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Head up Position

 

Option C: Incorrect. The head-up position is typically not used to treat hypotension following spinal anesthesia, as it may decrease venous return to the heart and exacerbate hypotension. Instead, the head-down position or left lateral tilt is often recommended to improve venous return and maintain blood pressure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Correct. IV Ephedrine is commonly used to treat hypotension following spinal anesthesia. It stimulates both α and β adrenergic receptors, leading to increased heart rate and blood pressure.

 

Option B. Correct. Administering IV fluids helps to increase intravascular volume, which can counteract the hypotension caused by spinal anesthesia-induced vasodilation and sympathetic blockade.

 

Option D. Correct. IV phenylephrine, a pure α adrenergic agonist, is effective in treating hypotension without causing tachycardia, as it increases vascular resistance and, consequently, blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the treatment of hypotension after spinal anesthesia, the head-down position is usually employed to enhance venous return and improve blood pressure, not the head-up position. Ephedrine and phenylephrine are effective vasopressors, and IV fluids help restore intravascular volume, all of which are part of the management strategy.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 9th Edition • Page no: 1442

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Neuraxial Anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bier’s Block

 

Option C: Incorrect. Bier’s block, or Intra-Venous Regional Anesthesia (IVRA), is not a form of neuraxial anesthesia. It is used for surgical procedures on extremities, such as the forearm or leg, where a tourniquet is applied, and anesthetic is injected into a vein.

 

BIER’S BLOCK:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Correct. Spinal anesthesia is a form of neuraxial anesthesia where local anesthetic is injected into the cerebrospinal fluid in the subarachnoid space.

 

Option B. Correct. Epidural anesthesia is another form of neuraxial anesthesia involving the injection of anesthetic in the epidural space.

 

Option D. Correct. Caudal anesthesia is a type of neuraxial block where the anesthetic is injected near the sacral hiatus and is often used in pediatric anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neuraxial anesthesia includes procedures such as spinal, epidural, and caudal anesthesia, where local anesthetics are placed around the central nervous system nerves. Bier’s block is not a form of neuraxial anesthesia as it is used for peripheral regional anesthesia of the extremities.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Pg 1784

choices.text: Aspirin should be stopped 7 days before surgery.
Unfractionated heparin should be stopped 7 days before surgery.
Fondaparinux should be stopped 7 days before surgery.
Clopidogrel should be stopped 7 days before surgery.

questions.text: Regarding Neuraxial Anesthesia and use of Anticoagulants, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clopidogrel should be stopped 7 days before surgery.

 

Drug Therapy During Neuraxial Anesthesia

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that Clopidogrel, due to its potent antiplatelet effects, should be discontinued 7 days before surgery to minimize the risk of bleeding when performing neuraxial anesthesia.

 

Ref: https://sfai.se/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/Full-Guideline-Regional-2018.pdf

choices.text: Onset of Analgesia takes about 20 minutes.
Local Anesthetic is Injected in Subarachnoid Space.
Most Common Site of Injection is L1-L2
Most Common Hemodynamic Consequence is Tachycardia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Local Anesthetic is Injected in Subarachnoid Space.

 

Option B: Correct. In spinal anesthesia, the local anesthetic is indeed injected into the subarachnoid space, which is the space between the pia mater and the arachnoid mater of the spinal cord.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. The onset of analgesia for spinal anesthesia typically occurs much faster, usually within 5 minutes, as the local anesthetic is directly injected into the cerebrospinal fluid, providing rapid onset of action.

 

Option C. Incorrect. The most common sites for spinal anesthesia are the L2–3 or L3–4 intervertebral spaces in adults, as the spinal cord typically ends at the lower border of the L1 vertebra. Injecting at L1-L2 could risk injury to the spinal cord.

 

Option D. Incorrect. The most common hemodynamic consequence of spinal anesthesia is hypotension, often accompanied by bradycardia, due to the blockade of sympathetic nerves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct site for spinal anesthesia is typically the L2–3 or L3–4 intervertebral spaces in adults to avoid injury to the spinal cord, and the most common hemodynamic consequence following spinal anesthesia is hypotension, not tachycardia.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Pg 1800-1830

questions.text: The anesthesiologist is administering a brachial plexus block by landmark guided technique. He gives 0.5% bupivacaine 20ml. After 10 minutes, the patient starts complaining of peri-oral numbness and starts getting seizures. What would be the treatment of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20% Intralipid

 

Option B: Correct. The 20% Intralipid solution is the treatment of choice for LAST. It acts by creating a lipid sink, which helps to absorb and neutralize the local anesthetic in the bloodstream, reducing its toxicity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. While Intralipid can be used to treat local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), the 10% solution is not the standard concentration recommended for the initial management of LAST.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Dantrolene sodium is used to treat Malignant Hyperthermia, a different condition that is triggered by certain anesthetics and Muscle Relaxants, not LAST.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Bromocriptine is a medication used to treat conditions such as Parkinson's disease and hyperprolactinemia, and it does not have a role in the management of LAST.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) is intravenous 20% Intralipid. This condition is characterized by initial excitatory symptoms followed by depressive cardiovascular symptoms and can be life-threatening if not promptly managed.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th Edition • Page no: 1047, 1715

choices.text: Prolonged PR Intervals
Widened QRS Complexes.
All of the above

questions.text: Which of these ECG changes are seen in Local Anesthesia Systemic Toxicity (LAST)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D: Correct. All the mentioned ECG changes can be seen in LAST as they reflect the disruption of normal cardiac conduction pathways due to local anesthetic toxicity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Correct. Sinus bradycardia can be seen in Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST) due to the effect of local anesthetics on cardiac sodium channels, leading to impaired cardiac conduction and decreased heart rate.

 

Option B. Correct. Prolonged PR intervals are indicative of atrioventricular (AV) nodal block, which can also be caused by the sodium channel-blocking effects of local anesthetics involved in LAST.

 

Option C. Correct. Widened QRS complexes suggest a delay in ventricular depolarization, which can occur in LAST due to impaired sodium channel function in the His-Purkinje system and ventricular myocardium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In LAST, ECG changes such as sinus bradycardia, prolonged PR intervals, and widened QRS complexes are observed due to the blockade of sodium channels by local anesthetics, which impairs action potential propagation and can lead to various arrhythmias and potentially cardiac arrest. Methods to prevent LAST include using a test dose, aspirating before injection, incremental dosing, and utilizing ultrasound guidance for regional anesthesia.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th Edition • Page no: 1047, 1715

questions.text: A patient undergoing VATS lobectomy has an epidural catheter in situ for post-operative pain relief. After 4 days there is a boggy swelling at the epidural insertion site and tenderness, and he also has fever. What is the probable organism which is the causative factor of this swelling?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus Epidermidis

 

Option B: Correct. Staphylococcus epidermidis is part of the normal skin flora and is a common cause of infections related to implanted devices, including epidural catheters. The presence of fever and a boggy swelling at the insertionsite suggests an infection that could be due to this organism.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. While Staphylococcus Aureus is a common cause of skin and soft tissue infections, it is not the most common organism associated with epidural catheter-related infections.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Streptococcus Viridans is a common cause of bacterial endocarditis and can cause bacterial meningitis following neuraxial blockade but is less commonly associated with epidural catheter site infections.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Hemophilus influenzae can cause respiratory tract infections and, occasionally, invasive diseases such as meningitis, but it is not typically associated with epidural catheter site infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely causative organism of an infection at the site of an epidural catheter insertion after a procedure like VATS lobectomy is Staphylococcus epidermidis, which is known for its association with device-related infections.

 

Ref: Miller's Anesthesia 9th Edition • Page No. 1428

choices.text: Delayed Onset of Action as compared to Spinal Anesthesia.
Smaller Size Needle is used.
Lesser Concentration Drug is used
Epidural Anesthesia is less dense as compared to Spinal Anesthesia

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature(s) of Epidural Anesthesia in comparison with spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Smaller Size Needle is used.

 

Option B: Incorrect. In epidural anesthesia, a larger needle is typically used compared to spinal anesthesia. The standard epidural needle size is usually 17–18 gauge, which is larger than the needles used for spinal anesthesia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Correct. Epidural anesthesia generally has a delayed onset of action when compared to spinal anesthesia because the anesthetic agent is injected into the epidural space, which is not in direct contact with the cerebrospinal fluid or the nerves as it is with spinal anesthesia.

 

Option C. Correct. In epidural anesthesia, the concentration of the local anesthetic used can be less than what is used in spinal anesthesia because the drug is administered into the epidural space and affects a larger area.

 

Option D. Correct. Epidural anesthesia may not be as dense or as profound as spinal anesthesia. This is due to the difference in administration sites, with epidural anesthesia being outside the dura mater, and spinal anesthesia being administered into the cerebrospinal fluid, resulting in a more immediate and denser blockade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key distinctions between epidural and spinal anesthesia include the onset of action, with epidurals having a slower onset, the size of the needle, with epidurals using a larger needle, and the density of anesthesia, with spinal anesthesia typically providing a denser block. It's important to recognize that a smaller size needle is not used for epidural anesthesia when compared to spinal anesthesia.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Pg 1830-1836

choices.text: Low Molecular Weight Heparin
Low Dose Aspirin

questions.solution:
Ans. D) Low Dose Aspirin

 

Explanation:

 

Low dose aspirin can be continued in neuraxial anesthesia as there is no increased chance of bleeding.

 

Drug Therapy During Neuraxial Anesthesia

 

Educational Objective 

Low dose aspirin can be continued in neuraxial anesthesia as there is no increased chances of bleeding.

Ref: https://sfai.se/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/Full-Guideline-Regional-2018.pdf

choices.text: Known Allergy to Bupivacaine and Lignocaine

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with a history of back pain is evaluated for a neuraxial blockade as part of the management plan. Which of the following patient factors is not considered a relative contraindication for performing a neuraxial blockade?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Known Allergy to Bupivacaine and Lignocaine

 

Option D: Correct. An allergy to local anesthetics such as bupivacaine and lignocaine is an absolute contraindication for using these drugs for neuraxial blockade. Alternative medications without cross-reactivity must be considered.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. While mental retardation is not an absolute contraindication, it may be considered a relative contraindication for neuraxial blockade due to potential difficulties with cooperation and communication during the procedure.

 

Option B. Incorrect. Sepsis can be a relative contraindication for neuraxial blockade due to the risk of spreading infection to the central nervous system.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Kyphoscoliosis, a severe spinal deformity, can be a relative contra-indication because it may make the technical performance of neuraxial blockade more challenging and potentially less effective or safe.

 

Educational Objective:

Allergies to specific anesthetics used in the procedure constitute an absolute contraindication, necessitating the use of alternative anesthetic agents or techniques. Conditions such as mental retardation, sepsis, and spinal deformities like kyphoscoliosis are considered relative contraindications, requiring careful risk-benefit analysis before proceeding with neuraxial anesthesia.

Ref: Miller's Anesthesia 9th Edition • Page no. 1420

choices.text: Mentally Retarded Patient
Allergy to Bupivacaine and Lignocaine

questions.text: Which of these is not a relative contraindication of performing Neuraxial Blockade?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Allergy to Bupivacaine and Lignocaine

 

Option D: Allergy to Bupivacaine and Lignocaine used in neuraxial blockade, is not a relative contraindication but an absolute contraindication. Using these agents in a patient with a known allergy could lead to anaphylaxis, a life-threatening allergic reaction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Mentally Retarded Patient is considered a relative contraindication because the patient may not be able to communicate effectively or cooperate during the procedure. Understanding and consent are important, and an inability to comply with instructions may increase the risk of complications during neuraxial blockade.

 

Option B: Sepsis is a relative contraindication due to the potential for seeding the central nervous system with bacteria during the procedure, which can lead to severe complications such as meningitis or abscess formation.

 

Option C: Severe spinal deformity, such as kyphoscoliosis, is a relative contraindication because it may make the procedure technically difficult or increase the risk of uneven distribution of the anesthetic agent, which can lead to incomplete blockade or higher risk of nerve damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An allergy to anesthetic agents, such as bupivacaine and lignocaine, is an absolute contraindication, not a relative one, due to the risk of severe allergic reactions.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology 5th Edition • Page no 948

choices.text: 4-6 hours prior to surgery
6-12 hours prior to surgery
12-24 hours prior to surgery
24-48 hours prior to surgery

questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis on intravenous unfractionated heparin therapy is posted for left femur open reduction internal fixation. You plan to do the case under spinal anesthesia. When would be the last dose of unfractionated heparin that you would give to this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4-6 hours prior to surgery

 

Explanation:

 

Unfractionated heparin has a relatively short half-life, generally 1 to 2 hours, which means it is typically cleared from the blood stream within 4-6 hours. Administering the last dose of heparin within this time frame before surgery allows for adequate anticoagulation to continue up to the point of surgery while minimizing the risk of bleeding complications associated with the neuraxial blockade.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Drug Therapy During Neuraxial Anesthesia

questions.text: Which of these is nottrue about Caudal Anesthesia in Children?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 0.5 mL/kg Dose of Bupivacaine is sufficient for Lumber and Sacral Dermatomes Block.

 

Option B: Incorrect. The dose of 0.5 mL/kg of bupivacaine may not be sufficient for a lumbar and sacral dermatomes block, as the required dose can vary based on the desired level of block and the concentration of the anesthetic. The Green Armitage formula provides a more detailed dosing scheme based on the level of anesthesia desired.

Armitage Formula: A) Dose for Lower Limb Surgery is 0.5ml/kg

                                B) Dose for Lower Abdominal Surgery is 0.75ml/kg

                                C) Dose for upper Abdominal Surgery is 1-1.5 ml/kg

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Correct. This measurement is consistent with anatomical data for pediatric patients, and knowing this distance is important for safely performing caudal anesthesia in children.

 

Option C. Correct. The sacral hiatus can be more difficult to identify in older children, increasing the failure rate of caudal anesthesia as children grow and their anatomy changes.

 

Option D. Correct. When placing an epidural catheter for continuous infusion, the standard practice is to advance it 2 to 3 cm into the epidural space, which is similar for both adults and pediatric patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Pediatric Anesthesia, Caudal Blocks are commonly used, but the anatomy can be challenging, especially in older children. Dosages must be carefully calculated, typically using a formula like the Green Armitage, to achieve the desired level of anesthesia. Understanding the correct dosing and anatomical considerations is essential for the safe administration of caudal anesthesia in children.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition • Page no 1840-1844

choices.text: Hyperesthesia
Hypoesthesia
Anesthesia Dolorosa
Allodynia

questions.text: Pain in area that lacks sensation is called as:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anesthesia Dolorosa

 

Option C: Correct. Anesthesia Dolorosa is a condition where there is pain in an area that otherwise lacks sensation, typically after nerve injury or a surgical procedure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. Hyperesthesia refers to an increased sensitivity to sensory stimuli, including pain, which is the opposite of the condition described.

 

Option B. Incorrect. Hypoesthesia is a condition characterized by decreased sensitivity to touch or sensation, not specifically pain in an area that lacks sensation.

 

Option D: Incorrect. Allodynia is the perception of pain from a stimulus that normally does not provoke pain, such as a light touch or moderate temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anesthesia Dolorosa is a rare and often challenging to treat condition where the patient experiences pain in an area of the body that is otherwise numb or lacks normal sensation. This condition can occur after certain types of nerve injury, including following procedures that affect the nerves.

 

Ref: Wall and Melzack’s textbook of Pain

questions.text: Which of these drugs is not used as first line therapy as per the WHO step ladder management of chronic cancer pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tramadol

 

Option B: Incorrect. Tramadol is a weak opioid and is used in the second step of the WHO analgesic ladder for pain that is not relieved by non-opioids alone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Correct. Paracetamol (Acetaminophen) is commonly used as a first-line agent in the WHO analgesic ladder for the management of cancer pain. It is classified as a non-opioid analgesic.

 

Option C. Correct. Diclofenac is a Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drug (NSAID) that can be used as part of the first step in the WHO analgesic ladder for cancer pain management.

 

Option D. Correct. Ibuprofen is another NSAID that is appropriate for use as a first-line agent in the WHO analgesic ladder for cancer pain management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the WHO analgesic ladder for chronic cancer pain management, non-opioids like paracetamol, diclofenac, and ibuprofen are considered first-line therapy. Tramadol, as a weak opioid, is not a first-line therapy but is used in the second step for pain that is not adequately controlled by non-opioid analgesics.

 

 

Ref:https://professionals.wrha.mb.ca/old/professionals/files/PDTip_AnalgesicLadder.pdf

choices.text: By the Clock
By the Pain Physician
By the Ladder
By the Mouth

questions.text: Which of these is not true regarding administration of drugs according to WHO analgesic step ladder?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) By the Pain Physician

 

Option B: Incorrect. The WHO analgesic ladder does not specify that medications should be administered "by the pain physician" exclusively. The principle emphasizes patient-centered care, allowing for self-administration where appropriate, and does not necessitate administration by a physician only.

 

The three main principles of the WHO analgesic ladder are: “By the clock, by the mouth, by the ladder”.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Correct. According to the WHO analgesic ladder, medications should be administered at regular intervals "by the clock" to maintain constant pain control, rather than waiting for pain to reoccur.

 

Option C. Correct. "By the ladder" refers to the stepwise approach to pain management recommended by WHO, starting with non-opioids, then adding mild opioids if necessary, and finally strong opioids for severe pain, along with adjuvant medications as needed.

 

Option D. Correct. The oral route is preferred for medication administration when possible, as per the WHO guidelines. It is considered safe, less invasive, and more convenient for patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO Analgesic ladder provides guidelines for pain management in a systematic manner, emphasizing regular timing ("by the clock"), oral administration ("by the mouth"), and a step wise approach to medication selection ("by the ladder"). It does not require that pain management be exclusively conducted by a pain physician, as the ladder is designed to guide treatment in various settings, including self-management under guidance.

 

Ref:https://professionals.wrha.mb.ca/old/professionals/files/PDTip_AnalgesicLadder.pdf

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient who underwent hemorrhoidectomy under spinal anesthesia uneventfully starts complaining of back pain with radiation or dysesthesia in the buttocks, thighs, hips and calves, occurring within 24 h after recovery from otherwise uneventful spinal anesthesia. What could be the causative drug for the same?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spinal Lignocaine

 

Option B: Correct. Lignocaine (Lidocaine), especially in hyperbaric formulations, has been associated with TNS, characterized by back pain and dysesthesias post-operatively.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. Bupivacaine is a commonly used local anesthetic for spinal anesthesia, but it is not typically associated with a high incidence of Transient Neurologic Symptoms (TNS).

 

Option C. Incorrect. Benzocaine is not commonly used for spinal anesthesia and is not associated with TNS in the context described.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Ropivacaine is less frequently associated with TNS compared to lignocaine and is commonly used for spinal anesthesia due to its favorable safety profile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to recognize that Transient Neurologic Symptoms (TNS) are most commonly associated with the use of lignocaine in spinal anesthesia and that alternative local anesthetics have a lower incidence of this complication. TNS typically resolves on its own but can be treated with epidural steroids if symptoms persist and are resistant to other medications.

 

Ref: Miller's Anesthesia 8th Edition • Page No. 1704

choices.text: Less Dose of Drug Required.
Duration of Anesthesia can be prolonged using a Catheter.
Easier to perform.
Less Traumatic Needle.

questions.text: Which of the following is an Absolute Advantage of Epidural over Spinal Anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duration of Anesthesia can be prolonged using a Catheter.

 

Option B: Correct. One of the distinct advantages of epidural anesthesia over spinal anesthesia is the ability to prolong anesthesia for an extended period through the use of an indwelling catheter, which allows for continuous infusion or repeated doses of the anesthetic as needed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. Epidural anesthesia typically requires a larger volume of drug than spinal anesthesia because the anesthetic must diffuse through a larger space and over a broader area to achieve the desired effect.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Epidural anesthesia is generally considered more technically challenging than spinal anesthesia due to the need to navigate through the epidural space without piercing the dura mater.

 

Option D. Incorrect. The needles used for epidural anesthesia are usually larger and can be more traumatic than the smaller, finer needles used for spinal anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ability to prolong the duration of anesthesia using an indwelling catheter is a significant advantage of epidural anesthesia over spinal anesthesia, making it a preferred choice in situations requiring extended pain management, such as labor and certain types of surgery.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition • Page no 1830-1840d

choices.text: Improved Quality of Block
Improved Analgesia due to Block
Increased Duration of Block
All of the above

questions.text: Additives to Local Anesthetic Drug used for Spinal Anesthesia have the following Advantages:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D: Correct. Each of the individual benefits listed contributes to the overall advantages of using additives with local anesthetics in spinal anesthesia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Correct. Additives can enhance the quality of the anesthetic block, making it more effective at providing anesthesia and analgesia.

 

Option B. Correct. Certain additives, particularly opioids, can significantly improve the analgesic effects of the spinal anesthetic block.

 

Option C. Correct. Additives such as epinephrine can prolong the duration of the anesthetic block by reducing vascular absorption and thereby extending the effect of the local anesthetic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incorporation of additives to local anesthetics in spinal anesthesia can improve the quality and analgesia of the block and extend its duration.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition • Page no 1838.
